Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
Project Number: 51027-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
September 2017 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Strategic Policy Study 
on Collaborative Control of Air Pollution and Carbon 
Emissions in the Transport Sector 
(Financed by the Climate Change Fund) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance 
(TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the formulation of a strategy that will 
simultaneously control air pollution and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the transport sector. 
The TA will help the Ministry of Transport (MOT) develop a (i) draft guideline on evaluating the 
co-benefits of policies and measures, and (ii) a strategy for the collaborative control of air pollution 
and GHG emissions, for consideration by the PRC government.1 The TA is included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan, 2017–2019 for the PRC.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Because of rapid economic development and urbanization, the PRC has been suffering 
from increasingly severe air pollution that occurs more frequently and in wider geographic areas, 
seriously  threatening  public  health  and  causing  domestic  and  international  concerns.  The 
transport sector is one of the main emission sources of air pollution and GHGs in the PRC. 
 
3.  The PRC’s national vehicle fleet reached 279 million in 2015 and is expected to increase 
by about 100 million by 2020. In 2015, nitrogen oxide (NO ) emissions from the transport sector 
x
reached 5.85 million tons, accounting for about 30% of national NO  emissions.3 Based on a 
x
source analysis of particulate matter less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM ) in nine cities 
2.5  
(Beijing,  Guangzhou,  Hangzhou,  Nanjing,  Ningbo,  Shanghai,  Shenzhen,  Shijiazhuang,  and 
Tianjin), the share of pollutant emissions from mobile sources varies from 15.0% to 52.1% of the 
total local emissions of PM .4 
2.5
 
4.  At the same time, the PRC has become the world's largest GHG emitter. The transport 
sector is one of the rapidly increasing sources of GHG emissions. According to the PRC report 
submitted to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, the carbon dioxide 
(CO ) equivalent emission from the transport sector in 2012 was as high as 797 million tons, 
2
which is much more than the total GHG emissions of all 50 small states (479 million tons of CO  
2
equivalent in 2012).5 Controlling GHG emissions in the transport sector is crucial to achieve the 
PRC’s GHG emission mitigation target. 
 
5.  To reduce air pollution and GHG emissions, the PRC government set national targets for 
their control. In 2016, the State Council issued the 13th Five-Year Plan for Ecological and 
Environmental Protection6 with the following air quality targets: compared with 2015 levels, by 
2020 (i) “good air quality days”7 must comprise at least 80% of each year, (ii) PM  emissions are 
2.5
reduced by 18% in cities, and (iii) sulfur dioxide and NO  emissions are reduced by 15%. On the 
x
GHG mitigation target, the PRC government committed to reduce CO  emissions per gross 
2
domestic product by 40%–45% by 2020, compared with the 2005 level, and reach CO  emission 
2
peak around 2030, with a best effort to reach the peak as early as possible, as its commitment 
under the Paris climate agreement. 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 13 July 2017. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2017–2019. Manila. 
3  Government  of  the  PRC.  Ministry  of  Environmental  Protection  (MEP).  2016.  China  Vehicle  Environmental 
Management: Yearly Report 2016. Beijing. http://dqhj.mep.gov.cn/jdchjgl/zhgldt. 
4  Mobile sources of air pollution include motor vehicles, airplanes, locomotives, and ships. 
5  World Bank. Total Greenhouse Gas Emissions. http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EN.ATM.GHGT.KT.CE. 
6  Government of the PRC. The State Council. 13th Five-Year Plan for Ecological and Environmental Protection. 
http://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2016-12/05/content_5143290.htm. 
7  The PRC environmental protection standard HJ633-2012 defines six levels of air quality. A day when the air quality 
index is equal to level 1 or 2 is considered a “good air quality day.”

2 
6.  The PRC government has developed and implemented polices and measures to control 
air pollution in the transport sector. In January 2016, the Ministry of Environmental Protection 
(MEP) released the Ordinance on Implementing the Fifth Phase Emission Standards of Vehicle,8 
which required all vehicles made in the PRC or imported from other countries to meet the Guo 
Biao-V (GB-V) national vehicle emission standard during April 2016–1 January 2018. In March 
2017, MEP, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the Ministry of Finance, 
and the National Energy Administration, together with the municipal and provincial governments 
of Beijing, Tianjin, Hebei, Shanxi, Shandong, and Henan, jointly released the Air Pollution Control 
Program 2017 in Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei and their Surrounding Region.9 The program has strict 
measures to control air pollutant emissions from transport and other sectors, including monitoring 
the pollutant emissions of vehicles, limiting entry of heavy trucks into urban areas, and supplying 
high-quality gas and diesel. In April 2017, MOT released the Notice on Implementation Program 
on Eco-Civilization Construction in the Transport Sector,10 which requires all vehicles to meet 
national emission standards when in operation. But these initiatives and measures on pollution 
control in the transport sector do not address GHG emissions. 
 
7.  The PRC government has also developed and implemented many policies and measures 
on GHG emission control. In October 2016, the State Council released the Work Program on 
GHG Emission Control during the 13th Five-Year Period,11 which mandates the development of 
low-carbon and green transport facilities, promotion of electric vehicles, and setting of strict GHG 
emission standards for vehicles. The NDRC initiated the National Plan on Coping with Climate 
Change (2014–2020), which includes GHG emission control measures for the transport sector, 
such as increasing the share of urban public transport to 30%, increasing transport efficiency to 
reduce GHG emissions per person-kilometer by 5% and per ton-kilometer by 13% of road 
transport by 2020, and increasing railway transport efficiency to reduce GHG emission intensity 
by 15% by 2020, compared with 2010.12 These emission control initiatives and measures, 
however, do not consider air pollutant emissions. 
 
8.  Unintended side effects may be caused by some air pollution control or GHG emissions 
reduction measures and technologies. Electric vehicles may not reduce GHG emissions if the 
charging electricity is from the low-efficiency coal-based power grid. Vehicle tail gas purifiers and 
diesel particulate filters can reduce air pollutants but will not reduce GHG emissions. Converting 
oil to gas for buses can reduce GHG emissions but buses when fueled with such converting gas 
will emit more NO . Burning diesel via the internal combustion engines of cargo vehicles is more 
x
powerful and energy saving, but will increase pollutant emissions. Without good management 
systems, low-carbon transport modes such as bicycle sharing may produce more waste from 
overproduction and short service lives. Some mitigation policies, technologies, and measures with 
good pollution and GHG emission reduction co-benefits may have high mitigation costs and may 
not be adopted if only a single environmental benefit (i.e., only GHG emission reduction or only 
pollution reduction) is considered. 
 
                                                
8  Government of the PRC. MEP and Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. Ordinance on Implementing 
the Fifth Phase Emission Standards of Vehicle. 
http://www.mep.gov.cn/gkml/hbb/bgg/201601/t20160118_326596.htm. 
9  Government of the PRC. MEP. Air Pollution Control Program 2017 in Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei and their Surrounding 
Region. http://dqhj.mep.gov.cn/dtxx/201703/t20170323_408663.shtml. 
10 Government of the PRC. MOT. Notice on Implementation Program on Eco-Civilization Construction in the Transport 
Sector. http://zizhan.mot.gov.cn/zfxxgk/bnssj/zhghs/201704/t20170414_2190311.html. 
11 Government of the PRC. State Council. Work Program on GHG Emission Control during the 13th Five-Year Period. 
http://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2016-11/04/content_5128619.htm. 
12 Government of the PRC. NDRC. 2014. National Plan on Coping with Climate Change (2014–2020). Beijing. 
http://www.ndrc.gov.cn/gzdt/201411/W020141104591413713551.pdf.

3 
9.  To ensure that the national air pollution control targets and GHG emission mitigation 
commitments  are  achieved,  the  PRC  government  should  prioritize  the  implementation  of 
technologies and measures with significant co-benefits for reducing air pollution and GHG 
emissions. To do so, the PRC government needs to evaluate the impact of GHG emissions when 
developing air pollution control policy and the impact of air pollution emissions when developing 
GHG mitigation policy to avoid those measures that help one aspect but harm another, such as 
reducing GHG emissions but increasing pollution. 
 
10.  The revised PRC Law on Air Pollution Prevention and Control issued in 2015 requires that 
policies and measures on controlling emissions should consider the co-benefits of reducing air 
pollution and GHG emissions, which is the first time the consideration of co-benefits has been 
required in a national policy document. This TA will help develop the policies and measures for 
collaborative control of air pollution and GHG emissions and enhance their co-benefits in the 
transport sector of the PRC. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: the objectives of controlling  air pollution and 
GHG emissions in the PRC’s transport sector in 2025 achieved.13 The TA will have the following 
outcome: policies on controlling air pollution and GHG emissions in the PRC’s transport sector 
improved.14 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Guideline on assessing the co-benefits of policies and measures for 
controlling air pollution and GHG emissions in the transport sector drafted. The TA will 
identify and review available and effective methods of assessing the benefits (including the health 
benefit) of policies and measures for controlling air pollution and GHG emissions in the transport 
sector (focusing on urban transport and roads), and develop a draft guideline that will include 
assessment and evaluation methods tailored to air pollution and GHG emission control in the 
transport sector. Specifically, the TA will explore for consideration an applicable evaluation 
method to reflect in an integrated way the effects of both air pollution and GHG emissions, and 
provide a tool to prioritize the consideration and implementation of technologies and measures 
with significant co-benefits in the transport sector. The TA will also explore partnerships with 
academic institutions. After the draft guideline is developed, the consultant team will carry out 
case studies by applying the draft guideline to selected real policies, measures, and technologies 
to verify the applicability and reliability of the methods. The TA will compile international best 
practices with good air pollution and GHG emission reduction co-benefits as a knowledge product. 
 
13.  Output 2: Strategy for enhancing collaborative control of air pollution and GHG 
emissions in the transport sector drafted. Based on output 1, the TA will develop a strategy 
that will include transport sector development (focusing on urban transport and roads) scenarios 
toward 2030 in the PRC; the optimization of controlling policies, measures, and technologies; and 
the implementation plan. The strategy will consider the possibility of incorporating incentive and/or 
market mechanisms to promote the implementation of the plan included in the strategy, which will 
be aimed at supporting the PRC government in achieving the national targets for air pollution and 
                                                
13 Because of the limited budget, the study will mainly focus on urban transport and roads. 
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
GHG emission control. The consultant team will submit the draft strategy to MOT and other line 
ministries for review, and then finalize and submit it to MOT for consideration. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The proposed TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.15 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff time, TA project office, 
office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB, through its East Asia Department’s Transport and Communication Division, will 
administer the TA. It will work closely with MOT’s Department of Comprehensive Planning, the 
executing agency of this TA. The Transport Planning and Research Institute of the PRC will be 
the implementing agency. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative  October 2017–September 2019 
implementation period 
Executing agency  Department of Comprehensive Planning, Ministry of Transport 
Implementing agency  Transport Planning and Research Institute 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by the Asian Development Bank 
  Individual consultant  10 person-months  $180,000 
selection  (individual, international) 
  Individual consultant  20 person-months  $90,000 
selection  (individual, national) 
Disbursement  The technical assistance resources will be disbursed following the Asian 
Development Bank's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
17.  Consulting services. The TA will need 30 person-months of consulting services from 
(i) an international environment and climate change specialist as team leader and a transport air 
pollution control specialist (10 person-months); and (ii) a national environment and climate change 
specialist in the transport sector as deputy team leader, a project coordinator, a GHG emission 
control  specialist,  and  a  transport  policy  specialist  (20  person-months).  ADB  will  engage 
consultants via individual consultant selection, given that individual experiences and qualifications 
are the main requirements to implement the TA activities.16 The consultants will be engaged by 
ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time 
to time).17 
 
18.  A  TA  team  consisting of  ADB  cross-divisional  specialists  will  work  closely  with  the 
executing and implementing agencies and the consultants, and will engage the line ministries and 
                                                
15 Established by ADB. 
16 ADB will consider output-based contracts for consulting services in line with ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 
2020: Action Plan. Manila. 
17 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
relevant agencies to seek valuable inputs for developing the TA outputs, and widely share TA 
output achievements after the completion of the project implementation. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented from 1 October 2017 to 30 September 2019. The consultants 
must submit the required TA reports on time, which are included in the terms of reference for 
consultants (footnote 17). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Strategic Policy Study on Collaborative 
Control of Air Pollution and Carbon Emissions in the Transport Sector, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

K  ey Activities with Milestones 
1.  Guideline on assessing the co-benefits of policies and measures for controlling air pollution 
and GHG emissions in the transport sector drafted 
1.1 Identify and review available and effective methods of assessing the benefits of policies and 
measures on controlling air pollution and GHG emissions in the transport sector (December 2017–
January 2018) 
1.2 Develop a draft guideline that includes assessment and evaluation methods tailored for controlling air 
pollution and GHG emissions in the transport sector (January–June 2018) 
1.3 Conduct case studies by applying the draft guideline to selected real policies, measures, and 
technologies to verify the applicability and reliability of the methods (July–November 2018) 
1.4 Develop a draft collection of international best practices with good co-benefits of air pollution and 
GHG emission reductions as a knowledge product (by April 2019) 
1.5 Finalize the guideline and the collection of international best practices (by August 2019) 
 
2.  Strategy for enhancing collaborative control of air pollution and GHG emissions in the 
transport sector drafted 
2.1 Develop transport development scenarios toward 2030 in the PRC, and air pollution and GHG 
emission scenarios of the transport sector of the PRC (December 2017–May 2018)

Appendix 1  7 
2.2 Prioritize the applicable policies and measures for enhancing the co-benefits of controlling air 
pollution and GHG emissions based on output 1 and applicable conditions, and draft the 
implementation proposal (October 2018–February 2019) 
2.3 Draft the strategy, with the proposed title Strategy for Enhancing Collaborative Control of Air Pollution 
and Carbon Emissions in the Transport Sector, against the national targets in air pollution and GHG 
emission control; and circulate the draft to MOT and other line ministries and experts for review and 
comments (March–May 2019) 
2.4 Finalize the strategy and TA completion report (August 2019)
